Yeah. I’d agree with that. I also don’t love locking into philosophy too much. Ideally you start from the problem and look outward on how to solve for it. But yeah, “innovation” means so many things to so many people. One shared truth - eliminating BS is key to be successful

Agree with this, and admittedly the company I spent many years at was not widely admired for its culture so I may have been weaned on a less than stellar example. That said the management approach to innovators dilemma is different from crossing the chasm no?

Yeah. Fair. I think the real winning is done when startups borrow from the experience of big programs and corporations enable people to act more entrepreneurial. If you can borrow, learn and correct properly, you become formidable

... and that’s a fault of@management. If the c-suite wants innovation they need to allow for a culture to form that challenges people, has objectives and accountability, etc. but that can’t be handed down. It needs to be crafted with participation and break silos. Not easy!

Well, then its your brilliamce that has revved your own engines and now that you are in charge of your own destiny, it’s all getting done. The problem in large orgs is just that - people aren’t hungry, are afraid to take risks and aren’t empowered to be truly entrepreneurial.

That said I appreciate the bigger point of good folks on both sides (for what it’s worth I’d love to work with Isobar :), but big co innovation is not the same thing as startup innovation. One is solving for innovators dilemma the other for crossing the chasm. Totally different.

Brilliance has nothing to do with it. In 15 yrs of big co & 3 yrs of my own startup there’s no comparison. Hyper growth and/or threat of annihilation makes engine run 24/7 solving external/market problems not internal/bureaucratic ones. Big co’s/startups are synergistic not same.

And the original point was related to the effectiveness of@innovation and ideas along with the ability to execute. Startups don’t have an advantage over large organizations. It depends on the situation. Plenty of large companies employ brilliant and creative problem solvers.

That’s true much of the time, but those “intrapreneurs” don’t last long unless there is a strategy and some level of incremental winning. Large companies aren’t all as slow and antiquated as one might think, but the majority do need help successfully commercializing innovation.
